questions.text: Which of these is the most common cause of chronic pancreatitis world wide?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Alcohol

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Chronic pancreatitis is often caused by prolonged alcohol use, leading to permanent structural changes and fibrosis in the pancreas, distinguishing it from acute pancreatitis where such changes are absent.

questions.text: A 54-year-old Lady with breast lump of size 6 x 7 cm, with skin ulceration and small area of inflammation over skin of breast belongs to what TNM stage?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) T4b

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In breast cancer staging , T4b is assigned for tumors with skin involvement such as ulceration or localized inflammation, while T4d is for generalized skin changes indicative of inflammatory breast cancer.
  • ➤ breast cancer staging
  • ➤ T4b
  • ➤ T4d

questions.text: Which of the following manifestations is not typically associated with multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1 syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Pheochromocytoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In MEN1 syndrome , the characteristic features are parathyroid hyperplasia, pancreatic endocrine tumors, and pituitary tumors . Pheochromocytoma is not part of MEN1 and is instead associated with MEN2 .
  • ➤ MEN1 syndrome
  • ➤ parathyroid hyperplasia, pancreatic endocrine tumors, and pituitary tumors
  • ➤ Pheochromocytoma
  • ➤ MEN2

questions.text: A 50-year-old Type 2 diabetic patient presents with fever and hypotension to the casualty. He gives a history of a boil in the perianal area which developed 2 weeks ago. On examination, the perianal area is as shown in the picture below. Identify the incorrect statement about this condition:

options.label: A
options.text: It is caused by multiple organisms

options.label: C
options.text: Surgical treatment is required in most cases

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Mortality is low

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fournier’s gangrene is a high-mortality, polymicrobial necrotizing fasciitis that requires urgent surgical debridement . It commonly spares the testes and is associated with systemic complications, particularly in diabetic and immunocompromised patients.
  • ➤ high-mortality, polymicrobial necrotizing fasciitis
  • ➤ urgent surgical debridement

questions.text: 25-year-old male presented with head trauma during football game. He has altered consciousness. CT brain shows the following. The next best step is:

options.label: B
options.text: Observe and give head high position

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Immediate craniotomy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Epidural hematomas require immediate surgical intervention, typically through craniotomy, to evacuate the hematoma and prevent brain herniation.
  • ➤ Epidural hematomas

questions.text: A 60-year-old female has recently undergone total thyroidectomy for a thyroid mass. The histopathological examination shows papillary thyroid cancer. Which of these is incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: Radioiodine scan is done after surgery

options.label: B
options.text: It is the most common primary thyroid malignancy

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Prognosis is poor

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Papillary thyroid carcinoma (PTC) is the most common thyroid malignancy in iodine-sufficient areas, has a good prognosis, and commonly spreads to the central (level 6) lymph nodes . Post-surgical management includes radioiodine scanning for residual disease detection.
  • ➤ Papillary thyroid carcinoma (PTC)
  • ➤ central (level 6) lymph nodes
  • ➤ radioiodine scanning

questions.text: Identify the role of the device:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Closed technique of pneumoperitoneum

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Veress needle is used to create a closed pneumoperitoneum by insufflating CO₂, allowing safe entry into the abdomen during laparoscopic procedures. It is preferred due to the reduced risk of air embolism and its non-combustible nature.
  • ➤ Veress needle
  • ➤ closed pneumoperitoneum

questions.text: A patient presents with acute abdominal pain after alcohol binge. The given finding is seen. What test is diagnostic of the given condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Serum lipase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For a patient presenting with abdominal pain and clinical signs suggestive of pancreatitis (e.g., Grey Turner’s sign), serum lipase is the primary diagnostic test, while CT abdomen is reserved for assessing complications or the severity of pancreatitis.
  • ➤ serum lipase
  • ➤ CT abdomen

questions.text: All of these are causes of bilious vomiting in a neonate at birth except?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Infantile pyloric stenosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Infantile pyloric stenosis does not present with vomiting immediately at birth but usually develops later in infancy (typically around 3-6 weeks of age), distinguishing it from other causes of neonatal vomiting such as duodenal atresia, jejunal atresia, and meconium ileus.

questions.text: Identify the scenario in which the technique is performed:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Liver resection

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pringle maneuver is used to control bleeding by clamping the hepatic artery and portal vein within the hepatoduodenal ligament during liver surgeries or liver trauma.

questions.text: An adult male is presented with duodenal ulcer is offered various surgical options for its treatment. Which of the surgical options listed below causes least complications?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Highly selective vagotomy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Highly selective vagotomy is the preferred surgical option for duodenal ulcer treatment when minimizing complications is a priority. It targets only the acid-producing areas, preserving gastric motility and resulting in fewer post-operative complications.

questions.text: A patient presents with painless PR bleed during defecation. The following is seen on proctoscopy. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Hemorrhoids

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hemorrhoids are characterized by painless rectal bleeding during defecation and appear as smooth, vascular protrusions on proctoscopy, distinguishing them from other anorectal conditions.
  • ➤ Grade 1 or 2 are managed by sclerotherapy/banding Grade 3 or 4 are managed by stapled procedures (image) or hemorrhoidectomy (Milligan Morgan)
  • ➤ Grade 1 or 2 are managed by sclerotherapy/banding
  • ➤ Grade 3 or 4 are managed by stapled procedures (image) or hemorrhoidectomy (Milligan Morgan)

questions.text: A chronic smoker gets cramping pain in his calf after walking about 500 m. What is the likely pathology?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Superficial femoral arterial block

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Calf pain during walking, particularly in a chronic smoker, is indicative of intermittent claudication, with the most common cause being a blockage in the superficial femoral artery.

questions.text: In Modified Radical Neck Dissection (MRND), which of the following structures is not preserved?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Submandibular gland

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In Modified Radical Neck Dissection (MRND), the submandibular gland is not preserved, while important structures like the sternocleidomastoid muscle, internal jugular vein, and spinal accessory nerve are spared to reduce morbidity.

questions.text: A 45-year female with history of migraine was taking regular NSAIDs. She experienced sudden onset abdominal pain with vomiting. Examination revealed generalized tenderness. X ray is as shown. Next step?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Take up for surgery

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of acute abdomen with pneumoperitoneum confirmed by X-ray, immediate surgery is indicated to manage perforation. CT is only necessary if the X-ray findings are inconclusive.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male who has been on treatment for varicose veins for the past 4 years, presents with eczema over the limb. What C stage does he belong to?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) C4a

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In the CEAP classification, C4a includes skin changes such as eczema and pigmentation related to venous disease, while more advanced skin changes like lipodermatosclerosis are categorized under C4b.
  • ➤ CEAP CLASSIFICATION
  • ➤ CEAP CLASSIFICATION
  • ➤ C1-Telang/RV C2- VV C3- edema C4a- pigment/eczema 4b- LDS/Atrophie blanche 4c- corona phlebectasia C5- healed ulcer C6- active ulcer
  • ➤ C1-Telang/RV
  • ➤ C2- VV
  • ➤ C3- edema
  • ➤ C4a- pigment/eczema 4b- LDS/Atrophie blanche 4c- corona phlebectasia
  • ➤ 4b- LDS/Atrophie blanche 4c- corona phlebectasia
  • ➤ 4b- LDS/Atrophie blanche
  • ➤ 4c- corona phlebectasia
  • ➤ C5- healed ulcer
  • ➤ C6- active ulcer
  • ➤ A- Asymptomatic
  • ➤ S- Symptomatic
  • ➤ R- Recurrent

questions.text: A young patient suffered from Blunt trauma to the abdomen and was brought to the Emergency room. He is unstable with a blood pressure of 90/60 mm of Hg. You are the doctor, basic resuscitation is done with Intravenous fluids, FAST is positive. He is not improving despite Intravenous fluids. The next step is?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Exploratory Laparotomy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of blunt abdominal trauma with an unstable patient and positive FAST, immediate exploratory laparotomy is the next step to manage internal bleeding or severe injuries.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man in an inebriated state fell in the bathroom and was taken to the casualty. He complained of intense pain in the suprapubic region. On examination, abdominal distention was present with generalized rigidity. No blood was seen at urethral meatus. Heart rate and blood pressure was normal. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Intraperitoneal bladder rupture

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Intraperitoneal bladder rupture is suspected when there is abdominal rigidity, distention, and signs of peritonitis following trauma, especially in cases of a full bladder and no signs of urethral injury.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male came with a history of progressive dysphagia, initially to solid foods and now to liquids too. He has also experienced significant weight loss over the past few months. Which of the following is the investigation of choice for diagnosing the underlying cause of his symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Upper GI endoscopy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of progressive dysphagia with weight loss, upper GI endoscopy with biopsy is the investigation of choice for diagnosing possible esophageal cancer.

questions.text: A patient presents with herniation of intestinal loop which passes along the spermatic cord and reaches till scrotum/cremaster muscle. What is the pathology?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Indirect inguinal hernia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ An indirect inguinal hernia follows the inguinal canal and can extend into the scrotum alongside the spermatic cord, unlike direct inguinal or femoral hernias.

questions.text: What is not true regarding renal stones?

options.label: A
options.text: Most common type of stone is triple phosphate

options.label: B
options.text: Small stones can be managed conservatively with pharmacotherapy

options.label: C
options.text: Soft stones can be removed by ESWL

options.label: D
options.text: ESWL should not be performed in pregnancy

questions.correct_answer: A. Most common type of stone is triple phosphate
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Most common type of stone is triple phosphate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The most common type of renal stone is calcium oxalate, and ESWL is a non-invasive option for treating soft stones but should not be used in pregnancy.

questions.text: 8-year-old boy presents with right sided acute scrotum. Examination reveals tenderness which worsens on lifting the testis. Which of these is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Testicular torsion

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of acute scrotum with tenderness that worsens upon testis elevation, testicular torsion should be suspected, necessitating urgent intervention to prevent irreversible damage.

questions.text: A road traffic accident patient is confused, opens his eyes on painful stimuli, flexes one limb on painful stimuli, and can localize the stimulus with the other limb. His Glasgow Coma Score is?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 11

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Glasgow Coma Score for a patient is calculated by assessing eye opening, verbal, and motor responses, and the highest motor response score is taken when there is variability.
  • ➤ Eye opening on pain: E2 Confused: V4 Localising pain: M5
  • ➤ Eye opening on pain: E2
  • ➤ Confused: V4
  • ➤ Localising pain: M5

questions.text: A teenage patient came with pain in RIF since 5 days and a palpable lump. He is currently afebrile and pulse is 90/minute. Blood investigation shows increased TLC. A diagnosis of phlegmonous appendicitis is suspected. What is the next step?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Conservative management

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For phlegmonous appendicitis with an appendicular lump, conservative management (Ochsner-Sherren regimen) is the preferred approach, followed by an interval appendectomy after 4-6 weeks. Immediate surgery is avoided to prevent complications.

questions.text: What should be the next step in a patient who presented in the emergency with respiratory distress, dilated neck veins and hyper-resonance on percussion?

options.label: A
options.text: Wide bore needle insertion in 5th intercostal space

questions.correct_answer: A. Wide bore needle insertion in 5th intercostal space
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Wide bore needle insertion in 5th intercostal space

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of suspected tension pneumothorax, immediate needle decompression is the first step, followed by imaging to confirm diagnosis and an ICD for definitive management.

questions.text: What is the management for a patient with a road traffic accident who presents with hemothorax, evidenced by 1600 ml of blood loss via a chest tube in 1 hour?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Thoracotomy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For traumatic hemothorax with high-volume blood loss (>1500 ml initially or >200-250 ml per hour for 3 hours), immediate thoracotomy is indicated to control the source of bleeding and stabilize the patient.

questions.text: Which of the following is considered a “sure sign” of wound dehiscence in a post-operative patient?

options.label: D
options.text: Widening of the abdominal scar with palpable edges

questions.correct_answer: C. Serosanguinous drainage from the wound
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Serosanguinous drainage from the wound

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Serosanguinous drainage from a post-operative wound is a critical early warning sign of wound dehiscence and should prompt immediate evaluation and intervention.

questions.text: According to European hernia society classification (EHS), hernia labelled as PL2 implies?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Primary indirect

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In the EHS classification, "P" indicates primary hernia, "L" indicates lateral (indirect) location, and "2" refers to the size of the defect (~3 cm).

questions.text: Identify the condition according to given image:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Trophic ulcer

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Trophic ulcers are commonly seen in neuropathic conditions like diabetes and are typically found on weight-bearing areas of the foot. They are deep, often painless, and surrounded by callosity.

questions.text: In a patient at risk of re-feeding syndrome, which of the following electrolyte imbalances is typically not associated with this condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Hypermagnesemia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Re-feeding syndrome is associated with hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia, and hypophosphatemia, with hypophosphatemia being the most consistent abnormality. Hypermagnesemia is not typically seen in this condition.

questions.text: A 34-year-old female patient presents with lower abdominal pain, frequent urination, and signs of dehydration. Physical examination reveals abdominal tenderness, and urine analysis indicates sterile pyuria. An image is provided. What is the most likely condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) TB kidney

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Unilateral kidney calcification with sterile pyuria and abdominal tenderness is indicative of renal tuberculosis, often termed "cement kidney."

questions.text: A patient has undergone cholecystectomy few days back and now the patient has presented with upper abdominal pain. MRCP was done which showed leak of bile from the cystic duct stump. Patient is hemodynamically stable. Which of the following should be the next line of management?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) ERCP and stenting

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In hemodynamically stable patients with a cystic duct stump bile leak post-cholecystectomy (Strasberg type A), ERCP with stenting is the preferred management to facilitate healing and prevent further complications.

questions.text: Identify the pathology in the newborn baby as shown in the image?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Anorectal malformation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ An invertogram X-ray is used specifically to diagnose anorectal malformations in newborns, helping to assess the location and presence of the rectal pouch.

questions.text: This instrument is commonly used for harvesting:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Split thickness graft

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Humby knife is a specialized instrument used for harvesting split-thickness skin grafts, which include the epidermis and part of the dermis, and is preferred for large surface coverage.

questions.text: Identify the procedure leading to the complication shown in image:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) ESWL

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Steinstrasse is a complication of ESWL and occurs when stone fragments obstruct the ureter, causing pain and possible hematuria.
  • ➤ ESWL

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presented to the surgery OPD. On examination, his left scrotal sac is empty and under-developed. On clinical examination the left testis was found in the superficial inguinal pouch. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Left ectopic testis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ An ectopic testis deviates from the normal path of descent and that the superficial inguinal pouch is the most common ectopic location. This is distinct from undescended or retractile testes, which follow different patterns of abnormal testicular position.
  • ➤ An ectopic testis deviates from the normal path of descent

questions.text: According to Wallace’s rule, genitalia represent what % of TBSA?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 1

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ According to Wallace's Rule of Nines , the genitalia represent 1% of the Total Body Surface Area (TBSA) in burn assessments.
  • ➤ Wallace's Rule of Nines
  • ➤ 1% of the Total Body Surface Area (TBSA)

questions.text: A 52-year-old patient with a history of chronic alcohol abuse presents to the clinic with complaints of lesion in the mouth. A picture of the patient's oral cavity is provided, which reveals several white patches on the tongue and inner cheek which can’t be rubbed off. Based on this presentation, what is the likely diagnosis and next step for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Leukoplakia-biopsy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Leukoplakia presents as a non-removable white patches or plaques that develop on the mucous membranes of the mouth, throat, or other areas of the body, often in patients with risk factors such as alcohol or tobacco use. It requires a biopsy, typically from the lesion's border, to rule out dysplasia or malignancy.
  • ➤ Leukoplakia presents as a non-removable

questions.text: 35-year-old healthy male is presented with a gunshot wound to right upper thigh region. On examination, patient was hemodynamically stable but had no palpable lower extremity pulses on the injured side. On exploration - superficial femoral artery was transected. Which of the following is the suture material to be used for vascular repair?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Polypropylene

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For vascular repairs, polypropylene is the preferred non-absorbable suture material due to its durability and minimal tissue reactivity, making it ideal for maintaining vessel integrity.
  • ➤ polypropylene

questions.text: The procedure shown in the image is used in the treatment of lower limb varicose veins. What is the procedure and what type of anesthesia is commonly used for this procedure?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) EVLA-local tumescent anesthesia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Endovenous Laser Ablation (EVLA) for varicose veins is typically performed under local tumescent anesthesia for patient comfort and effective pain management.
  • ➤ Endovenous Laser Ablation (EVLA)
  • ➤ local tumescent anesthesia

questions.text: At what angle should the skin be pierced with the needle, while suturing the skin using interrupted sutures?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 90 degrees

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The correct angle for inserting the needle in skin suturing is 90 degrees , which ensures optimal tissue approximation and reduces the risk of wound dehiscence.
  • ➤ 90 degrees

questions.text: Identify the correct diagnosis on the basis of given image of newborn baby?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Exstrophy bladder

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Bladder exstrophy is a congenital condition where the bladder is exposed through an abdominal wall defect and requires surgical intervention to close the defect and protect the bladder tissue.
  • ➤ Bladder exstrophy

questions.text: A 30-year-old housewife accidentally spilled hot tea all over herself at a kitty party. She gets this lesion on her right thumb which is very painful and erythematous. Which parts of the skin are affected in this scenario?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Epidermis + superficial dermis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Superficial partial-thickness (second-degree) burns involve the epidermis and superficial dermis , presenting with erythema, blistering, and significant pain.
  • ➤ Superficial partial-thickness (second-degree) burns
  • ➤ epidermis and superficial dermis

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl from Maharashtra presented with pain in the right upper abdomen, lump in the abdomen. Investigation revealed conjugated hyper-bilirubinemia. USG abdomen showed dilated CBD of 6 mm. What will be your next investigation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) MRCP

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a young child with conjugated hyperbilirubinemia and a dilated CBD, the investigation of choice is MRCP to confirm and assess choledochal cysts.

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman presents with a history of decreased fetal movements and respiratory distress is observed in her newborn. On examination, the neonate appears cyanotic with increased work of breathing. Auscultation reveals bowel sounds in the left hemithorax. Chest x-ray showed multiple air fluid levels in left thorax. Which of the following congenital anomalies is most likely responsible for these findings?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Congenital diaphragmatic hernia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Congenital diaphragmatic hernia often presents with neonatal respiratory distress, bowel sounds in the chest, and air-fluid levels on X-ray. The most important prognostic factor is the degree of pulmonary hypoplasia and pulmonary hypertension.

questions.text: Identify the condition in the image:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Omphalocele

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Omphalocele is a congenital defect where abdominal organs herniate through the umbilical region, covered by a membrane. The presence of a covering membrane distinguishes it from other abdominal wall defects.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about nephroblastoma?

options.label: C
options.text: Treatment is by chemotherapy and surgery

options.label: D
options.text: It is the most common intra-abdominal malignancy in children

questions.correct_answer: D. It is the most common intra-abdominal malignancy in children
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) It is the most common intra-abdominal malignancy in children

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Nephroblastoma is a common pediatric kidney cancer, other intra-abdominal malignancies, like neuroblastoma, are more common in children.

questions.text: A patient has undergone surgery as shown in the image below. After this surgery, the patient presents with pallor, dizziness and sweating whenever he has a large meal. What could this be?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Dumping syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Dumping syndrome is a postoperative complication associated with gastric surgeries where rapid gastric emptying leads to symptoms like dizziness, sweating, and pallor, especially after large meals.

questions.text: A lady was incidentally diagnosed with a 1.5 cm solid mass in her Gall Bladder on USG which is immobile and it is diagnosed as a gall bladder polyp. She is asymptomatic. What is the next step in the management?

options.label: A
options.text: Reassure the patient and follow up

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Laparoscopic Cholecystectomy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Gall bladder polyps greater than 1 cm should generally be managed with cholecystectomy due to the elevated risk of malignancy.
  • ➤ cholecystectomy

questions.text: Pressure required to cause a pressure sore is?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 30 mm of Hg

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The pressure required to cause a pressure sore is approximately 30 mm of Hg. Preventive measures, such as the use of air mattresses and regular repositioning, help reduce the risk of pressure ulcer formation.

questions.text: Barium swallow image demonstrated below indicates:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Zenker’s diverticulum

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Zenker’s diverticulum is best identified on a lateral barium swallow image as a posterior outpouching in the cervical esophagus, unlike other esophageal conditions that primarily affect the thoracic region.

questions.text: In an asymptomatic patient, on routine screening a small mass was detected in the rectum which looked like a suspected neoplasm. What is the next step in the management?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Sigmoidoscopy with lesion biopsy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The first step in managing a suspected neoplastic mass in the rectum is sigmoidoscopy with biopsy to confirm the diagnosis before proceeding with staging and treatment planning.
  • ➤ sigmoidoscopy with biopsy

questions.text: A patient came with the pain in right hypochondrium. Blood investigation shows AST-22 IU/l and ALT-27 IU/ L, serum direct bilirubin levels -6mg% and ALP-400 mg % What should be the next investigation in this patient?

options.label: C
options.text: Hepatitis A and Hepatitis E markers

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) USG abdomen

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of suspected obstructive jaundice, the first-line investigation is an ultrasound of the abdomen to evaluate the liver, gallbladder, and bile ducts before considering further imaging modalities.
  • ➤ first-line investigation is an ultrasound of the abdomen

questions.text: Identify the organism for which this test is performed:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) H pylori

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The CLO test (rapid urease test) detects H. pylori by identifying urease activity in antral mucosa obtained through endoscopy. A positive result appears as a pink color change.

questions.text: A 56-year-old male presents to the emergency with abdominal pain and an episode of binge drinking in shock with a BP of 70/50 mm Hg and HR of 115/min. The oxygen saturation of the patient is 89%. Serum creatinine level was 2.4 mg/dL. What is the likely diagnosis based on the CT image shown below?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Severe acute pancreatitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Severe acute pancreatitis is defined by the presence of systemic organ failure and is commonly associated with necrosis seen on imaging. A history of binge drinking and clinical indicators of organ failure strongly point to this diagnosis.

questions.text: A patient was operated on for benign prostatic hyperplasia. On evaluation, incidentally, cancer of the Prostate was detected and on further workup was found to have metastasis. Which of the following drug is used for treatment?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Bicalutamide

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Androgen deprivation therapy (ADT) is the mainstay for metastatic prostate cancer, and bicalutamide is an androgen receptor blocker used in combination with GnRH analogs to inhibit androgen effects and manage metastatic disease.
  • ➤ Androgen deprivation therapy (ADT)
  • ➤ bicalutamide

questions.text: 50-year-old male, known case of cirrhosis of liver presents with abdominal lump. Imaging reveals solitary 3 x 4 cm nodule with rapid enhancement of mass. Which clinical criteria would decide suitability for treatment by liver transplant?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Milan criteria

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Milan criteria guide liver transplant eligibility in patients with hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). They require a single tumor ≤ 5 cm or up to three tumors ≤ 3 cm each, without vascular invasion or extrahepatic spread.

questions.text: In a degloving injury, structures that get stripped include:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Skin + subcutaneous fat

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a degloving injury, the skin and subcutaneous fat are stripped away, exposing the underlying structures such as the deep fascia, tendons, or muscle.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presents with painless bleeding in stools. He has been smoking a pack of cigarettes daily since 20 years. P/R examination shows no hemorrhoids or local perianal lesion. What is the likely etiology?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Ca rectum

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In elderly patients with a history of smoking and painless rectal bleeding, colorectal cancer should be a primary consideration in the differential diagnosis.

questions.text: Per-oral endoscopic myotomy operation is preferred for:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Achalasia cardia type 3

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Per-oral endoscopic myotomy (POEM) is the preferred treatment for type 3 achalasia, characterized by esophageal spasms, as it allows targeted relief of spastic contractions in addition to addressing lower esophageal sphincter dysfunction.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with left flank pain and mild hematuria. Urine analysis shows dumbbell shaped crystals. What is the investigation of choice to diagnose the condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Plain CT KUB

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Plain CT KUB is the investigation of choice for evaluating suspected renal or ureteric stones due to its high sensitivity for detecting calculi without the need for contrast, making it effective and efficient in confirming urinary stone diagnosis.
  • ➤ Plain CT KUB

questions.text: 45/F presents with bleeding PR and pain in LIF since 2 days. Colonoscopy is performed as shown. Likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Sigmoid diverticulosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sigmoid diverticulosis commonly presents with painless or mildly painful bleeding PR localized to the left lower quadrant. Colonoscopy typically reveals multiple diverticula, which are mucosal outpouchings in the sigmoid colon.

questions.text: Which of these is incorrectly matches in Glasgow Coma Score for head injury?

options.label: A
options.text: Eye opening on painful stimulus alone: E2

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Confused speech: V2

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The correct scoring of the Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) :
  • ➤ Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS)
  • ➤ Eye response (E) ranges from 1 (no response) to 4 (spontaneous opening). Verbal response (V) ranges from 1 (no response) to 5 (oriented conversation). Motor response (M) ranges from 1 (no response) to 6 (obeys commands).
  • ➤ Eye response (E) ranges from 1 (no response) to 4 (spontaneous opening).
  • ➤ Verbal response (V) ranges from 1 (no response) to 5 (oriented conversation).
  • ➤ Motor response (M) ranges from 1 (no response) to 6 (obeys commands).

questions.text: A 25-year-old male was brought to the emergency department after road traffic accident. On examination, his sensorium was altered and GCS was 5/15. NCCT head was performed and was a normal study. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Diffuse axonal injury

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Diffuse axonal injury (DAI) is a common cause of altered sensorium and low GCS in patients with a normal NCCT following high-impact trauma. MRI is the preferred modality for confirmation.

questions.text: A 50-year-old smoker male presents with retrosternal burning pain. Endoscopy shows salmon colored tongue like projections at GE junction. Biopsy shows mucous secreting goblets cells with intestinal metaplasia. What is the risk of malignancy?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 0.4%

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Non-dysplastic Barrett’s esophagus carries a low risk of malignant progression to esophageal adenocarcinoma, estimated at approximately 0.4% annually . This risk is significantly higher in Barrett’s esophagus with dysplasia.
  • ➤ Non-dysplastic Barrett’s esophagus
  • ➤ 0.4% annually

questions.text: All of these are indications for CT brain in head trauma except:

options.label: B
options.text: Any Head injury in patient > 65 years

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) GCS < 15 at any point

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Indications for CT brain in head trauma include focal neurological deficits, extremes of age, amnesia > 30 minutes, and persistent or severe GCS drop (<13). Multiple episodes of vomiting are also an important indicator.

questions.text: A central line was being put in the Subclavian vein and the patient collapsed during insertion of the central line. On examination, breath sounds suddenly were found to be absent on the side of insertion of Central line, on Percussion there was hyper resonance on the same side of insertion of the central line. Most likely cause in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Pneumothorax

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pneumothorax is a common complication of central line placement, especially in the subclavian approach, and presents with absent breath sounds and hyperresonance on the affected side. Immediate recognition and management are crucial in such cases.
  • ➤ Pneumothorax

questions.text: According to ATLS, in ABCD of trauma, D stands for?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Assessment of neurological status

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In the ATLS trauma protocol , "D" stands for Disability , which involves assessing the patient’s neurological status through GCS scoring and pupil evaluation to identify any acute neurological impairments.
  • ➤ ATLS trauma protocol
  • ➤ Disability
  • ➤ neurological status

questions.text: Which patient category is classified as "green" according to the triage system?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Ambulatory patients

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a triage system, the green category is used for ambulatory patients with minor injuries, indicating they are low-priority and can safely wait for treatment. The color-coded triage system helps efficiently manage resources by prioritizing care based on urgency.
  • ➤ green category
  • ➤ ambulatory patients
  • ➤ A. Ambulatory patients - Green
  • ➤ B. Medium risk patients - Yellow
  • ➤ C. High risk patients - Red
  • ➤ D. Dead patients - Black

questions.text: Which of the following method of mesh plasty is shown in TEP repair of inguinal hernia?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Preperitoneal Sublay

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In TEP (Totally Extraperitoneal) repair of inguinal hernia, the mesh is placed in the preperitoneal sublay position, identifiable by the pubic bone ("White House Sign") and absence of omentum or intestines, which are seen in IPOM repairs.

questions.text: Which of the following procedure is done for the treatment of Pilonidal sinus as shown?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Transposition flap

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Limburg (rhomboid) flap is a type of transposition flap commonly used in pilonidal sinus surgery, involving lateral movement of tissue to fill the defect and minimize tension, ensuring effective wound healing and reduced recurrence.

questions.text: Which of these is not a risk factor for cholangiocarcinoma?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Hepatitis B infection

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hepatitis C, not Hepatitis B, is a significant risk factor for cholangiocarcinoma. Other important risk factors include Caroli’s disease, primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC), and liver fluke infections (Opisthorchis viverrini or Clonorchis sinensis).

questions.text: A patient was brought to the emergency with flame burns. On clinical evaluation there were deep burns involving the left upper limb, the right upper limb and the anterior aspect of chest and abdomen. How much percentage of burns would it be classified as?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 36%

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Wallace’s Rule of Nines is used to estimate TBSA in burn injuries: each upper limb is 9%, the anterior torso (chest and abdomen) is 18%, and adding these percentages gives a quick and accurate estimate of total burns.

questions.text: A patient suffered burns following which the surgical procedure was done as shown in the image. Which of the following best describe the likely procedure done?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Thiersch skin graft

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Thiersch (split-thickness) skin grafts are commonly used for burn wound coverage. They are meshed to increase surface area, allow for better drainage, and facilitate healing over large defects.

questions.text: A 27-year-old lady presented to OPD with the complaint of pain and redness in her breast with low-grade fever. On clinical examination 5 X 4 cm area of redness was noted in the breast with ipsilateral axillary lymph node enlargement. What should be the preferred management in this lady?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Antibiotics and breast support

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In lactational mastitis, the preferred treatment is antibiotics and breast support. Incision and drainage are only indicated if there is a breast abscess. Mammography is not recommended in women under 40 years for acute breast conditions.

questions.text: Arrange the sequence of damage control surgery: Hemorrhage control Definitive repair Abdomen closure Resuscitation in ICU
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 1, 4, 2, 3

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The sequence of damage control surgery includes hemorrhage control, resuscitation in the ICU, definitive repair, and abdomen closure. This approach prioritizes life-saving interventions over definitive treatment to stabilize critically injured patients.

questions.text: A patient underwent cholecystectomy. The histopathology reveals carcinoma with invasion into the muscularis propria. What is the next best step?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Extended cholecystectomy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For T1b gallbladder carcinoma (muscularis propria invasion), the next step is an extended cholecystectomy, which includes wedge resection of the liver tissue near the gallbladder fossa and regional lymphadenectomy. Surveillance is adequate only for T1a tumors limited to the mucosa.

questions.text: Shown below is a popular sign that occurs in acute appendicitis. What is the name of this sign?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Rovsing’s sign

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Rovsing’s sign is elicited by palpating the left lower quadrant, causing pain in the right lower quadrant due to peritoneal irritation, and is a key diagnostic finding in acute appendicitis.

questions.text: Which of these are true regarding colon cancer? Colon cancer can be hereditary Right and left sided colon cancer vary in presentation Onco-surgical resections are based on vascularity of affected part It frequently metastasizes to the liver
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) All are correct

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ All of the statements are correct. Colon cancer can have hereditary causes (FAP, HNPCC), right and left-sided tumors differ in presentation, oncological resections are based on vascular supply, and the liver is the most frequent site of metastasis for colorectal cancer.

questions.text: What kind of surgical wound is open cardiac massage categorized as?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Contaminated

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Open cardiac massage is classified as a contaminated surgical wound due to the emergency setting and major breach in sterility. The risk of surgical site infection (SSI) for contaminated wounds is 10–20% without antibiotics.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presented with recurrent painful perianal nodules on buttocks with serous discharge. The image is given below. What is the best diagnostic test?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) MRI perineum

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ MRI perineum is the gold standard for evaluating perianal fistulas, providing detailed information about fistula tracts, abscesses, and their relationship with the anal sphincter. Contrast fistulogram is less accurate and requires a patent tract, while sigmoidoscopy is not suitable for this purpose.

questions.text: Which of the following is contraindicated in a neonate with a scaphoid abdomen and respiratory distress?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Bag & mask ventilation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In neonates with congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH), bag and mask ventilation is contraindicated as it can cause gastric distension and worsen herniation, further compromising lung function. Intubation and controlled ventilation are the preferred methods of management.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presents with chronic progressive abdominal distension and recent onset hiccoughs. On inquiry, he is passing neither flatus nor stools. X ray shows dilated loop of bowel with two limbs running diagonally across the abdomen from right to left, with two fluid levels seen. Likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Sigmoid volvulus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sigmoid volvulus presents with progressive abdominal distension, inability to pass flatus or stools, and classic "coffee-bean" appearance on X-ray with two fluid levels. Cecal volvulus has a single fluid level and appears as a comma-shaped "embryosign."

questions.text: Identify the true statement regarding retroperitoneal hematoma:

options.label: A
options.text: Zone 3 hematomas should always be explored

options.label: B
options.text: Mattox maneuver involved medialization of splenic flexure and descending colon

options.label: C
options.text: Vessels injured in zone 1 should be embolized

options.label: D
options.text: Pelvic trauma with fracture should be explored

questions.correct_answer: B. Mattox maneuver involved medialization of splenic flexure and descending colon
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Mattox maneuver involved medialization of splenic flexure and descending colon

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Mattox maneuver (left medial visceral rotation) is used to access the abdominal aorta by medializing the splenic flexure and descending colon. Management of retroperitoneal hematomas depends on the zone, with Zone 1 requiring exploration, Zone 2 often conserved, and Zone 3 managed non-operatively.

questions.text: On the basis of given image, which cancer is operated here?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Carcinoma head of pancreas

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Whipple procedure (pancreaticoduodenectomy) is performed for carcinoma of the pancreatic head or periampullary region. It involves removal of the head of the pancreas, duodenum, and part of the bile duct, with reconstruction via pancreatico-jejunostomy, hepatico-jejunostomy, and gastro-jejunostomy.

questions.text: In the image given, the marked balloon is inflated with:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 300 cc air

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Sengstaken-Blakemore tube is used for tamponade in bleeding esophageal varices. The gastric balloon (distal) is inflated with 300 cc air, and the esophageal balloon (proximal) is inflated with 30-40 cc air as per clinical guidelines.

questions.text: Which of these is the most common late complication of TIPSS for portal hypertension?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Shunt blockage

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Shunt blockage is the most common late complication of TIPSS, occurring due to thrombosis, stenosis, or intimal hyperplasia. Hepatic encephalopathy is a common early complication but not the primary late complication.

questions.text: Which of these is the most common type of hernia in females?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Indirect inguinal

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The most common type of hernia in females is the indirect inguinal hernia. Femoral hernias are the second most common in females and occur more frequently in women compared to men.

questions.text: A 50-year female recently diagnosed diabetic presents to OPD with rash as shown in the image. She is also suffering from clinical depression and is under medications. What blood investigation will you advise?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Fasting Glucagon

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The classical "Four D’s" of Glucagonoma syndrome are Dermatitis (necrolytic migratory erythema), Diabetes, Depression, and Deep vein thrombosis. The investigation of choice is fasting glucagon levels.

questions.text: All are advantages of minimal access surgery except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Short learning curve

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Minimal access surgery provides reduced postoperative pain, easier access to deep cavities, and decreased heat loss, but it has a longer learning curve compared to open surgery.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents to the emergency room with nausea, vomiting, loss of appetite and abdominal pain. She has a history of ileocecal TB, for which she is on treatment. On physical examination, abdomen is tender and distended, with increased peristalsis. An abdominal radiograph shows as below. What is the diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Distal obstruction in the small intestine

questions.correct_answer: A. Distal obstruction in the small intestine
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Distal obstruction in the small intestine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The step-ladder appearance of air-fluid levels on abdominal radiograph, along with hyperperistalsis and symptoms of obstruction, is characteristic of a mechanical small bowel obstruction.

questions.text: Which of these is not a contra-indication for BCT?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Palpable axillary LN

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The presence of palpable axillary lymph nodes is not a contraindication for breast-conserving therapy; however, conditions like diffuse microcalcifications, a history of chest radiation, and multicentric tumors are contraindications.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient underwent an open Lichtenstein hernioplasty for inguinal hernia repair. Postoperatively, the patient complained of persistent pain at the surgical site, which worsened with physical activity. On examination, the surgical wound appeared well-healed, and there was no sign of infection. The patient was advised to take pain medication and to avoid strenuous physical activity. Physical therapy and nerve blocks were also recommended to manage the pain. The patient's symptoms improved gradually over time, and he was able to return to his normal activities after several weeks. Which of the following is the most common complication of inguinal hernia repair surgery?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Chronic pain

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Chronic pain is the most common long-term complication following inguinal hernia repair surgery, necessitating appropriate management strategies to improve patient outcomes.

questions.text: A patient underwent laparoscopic cholecystectomy. Identify the structure as marked:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Cystic duct

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The cystic duct connects the gallbladder to the common bile duct and is positioned away from the liver in the critical view of safety during a laparoscopic cholecystectomy.
  • ➤ cystic duct

questions.text: A patient presented with red, pulsatile swelling in the inguinal region. Which of the following is more appropriately done in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: First Angiography to confirm the diagnosis

questions.correct_answer: A. First Angiography to confirm the diagnosis
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) First Angiography to confirm the diagnosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pulsatile swellings, particularly in the inguinal region, are likely vascular in origin (e.g., femoral artery aneurysm). Angiography is essential for diagnosis before any intervention.

questions.text: The term “nocturia” implies waking up at night to pass urine at least how many times, in a patient with urinary tract disease?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Once

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Nocturia is diagnosed if a person regularly wakes up even once at night to urinate in the presence of urinary tract disease or related pathology.

questions.text: Identify the treatment of an incidentally detected lump shown in the image:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Follow up

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A horseshoe kidney is an incidental finding on imaging that requires follow-up and monitoring if asymptomatic. Interventions are only considered if complications arise.

questions.text: 40/F presents with large woody hard goitre. She also complaints of bilateral flank pain. Histopathology as shown below. What is her Diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Riedel’s thyroiditis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Riedel’s thyroiditis presents with a hard, "woody" thyroid gland and may involve fibrosis of adjacent tissues. Diagnosis is primarily clinical, supported by histopathological findings.

questions.text: Advanced bipolar energy sources can coagulate vessels directly of diameter:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Up to 7 mm

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Advanced bipolar energy sources can effectively coagulate vessels up to a diameter of 7 mm. They are widely used for safe and efficient vessel sealing in surgical procedures.

questions.text: Which number knife is used for arteriotomy?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 11

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The #11 blade is the preferred knife for arteriotomy due to its sharp, pointed design, enabling precise incisions into blood vessels.
